required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Examining the Long-Term Risks of Oophorectomy
clinical_study.official_title: Ovarian Conservation: Long-Term Health Outcomes From the Nurse's Health Study.

brief_summary.textblock: At the time of hysterectomy for benign disease, the overall health benefits of preserving ovarian function in a large population of women have not been established.

detailed_description.textblock: We are conducting a prospective, observational study of 32,175 women participants of the Nurse's Health Study who had a hysterectomy with or without removal of both ovaries. We are evaluating mortality and morbidity due to the following conditions: coronary heart disease, stroke, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, other cancer, hip fracture and death from all causes.

primary_outcome.measure: mortality and morbidity due to the following conditions: coronary heart disease, stroke, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, other cancer, hip fracture and death from all causes.

secondary_outcome.measure: The effect of postmenopausal hormone use on mortality and morbidity due to the following conditions: coronary heart disease, stroke, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, other cancer, hip fracture and death from all causes.

arm_group.description: all women having a hysterectomy with oophorectomy
all women having a hysterectomy without removal of ovaries

study_pop.textblock: Nurses' Health Study I, which included 122,701 married registered nurses living in 11 U.S. states and who were ages 30 to 55 in 1976

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women who had hysterectomies were classified into simple hysterectomy or hysterectomy with both ovaries removed.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Evidence of cancer, coronary heart disease (MI or Angina Pectoris), stroke, or hip fracture before entering the study were excluded. Cancer as an indication for hysterectomy also excluded.
- Women reporting unilateral oophorectomy, unknown oophorectomy status, unknown age of hysterectomy, or those who had oophorectomy before hysterectomy were excluded.

reference.citation: Parker WH, Broder MS, Liu Z, Shoupe D, Farquhar C, Berek JS. Ovarian conservation at the time of hysterectomy for benign disease. Obstet Gynecol. 2005 Aug;106(2):219-26.
